Graphical abstract The impact of catalyst deactivation due to sintering on the activity and properties of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was systematically investigated. Additionally, the effects of various additives on methanol yield and catalyst stability during CO2/H2 hydrogenation were evaluated. Additives such as methanol were confirmed to enhance catalytic activity, while components with high dipole moments exhibited a poisoning effect. Interestingly, despite their deactivating influence on activity, these polar additives significantly improved catalyst stability. It is presumed that highly polar species adsorb onto the catalyst surface, displacing water that would otherwise promote crystal growth of copper and zinc oxides, leading to deactivation. A combined additive strategy using methanol (to boost activity) and propylene carbonate (to enhance stability) offers a novel approach to significantly slow down Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst deactivation during gas-phase CO2 hydrogenation, without compromising initial activity compared to conventional additive-free systems. Thus, catalyst stability can be effectively improved through the addition of appropriate components to the feed, without sacrificing reaction rate. Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system represents the preferred catalyst for methanol synthesis from CO/CO2/H2 reactants (reaction (1) and (2)) [1]. Since methanol is one of the most important basic chemicals, the use of the greenhouse gas CO2 as the carbon source for its synthesis would be particularly desirable. However, especially with a CO2-rich reactant composition, the initial activity of the catalyst is not sustained and the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system deactivates quickly [2–4]. (1) CO 2 + 3 H 2 ⇌ CH 3 O H + H 2 O (2) CO + 2 H 2 ⇌ CH 3 O H The deactivation of the catalyst is associated with a reduction of specific surface area, a decrease in metallic copper on the surface, and an increase in the crystal sizes of Cu and ZnO [4–7]. These changes of the catalyst properties will be summarized in the following under the term of sintering. There is some uncertainty about the deactivation mechanism [1]. Liquid phase experiments showed that the catalyst sintered to varying degrees depending on the presence and amount of water [8]. The availability of water as a starting point for sintering would also explain the increased deactivation speed observed for CO2-rich feed gas compositions compared to the CO based catalysis. In contrast to the case of CO-rich feed gas methanol synthesis, the use of CO2-rich feed gas leads to an increased production of water (1) as well as by the rWGSR (reverse water gas shift reaction, 3) and thus increases the deactivation of the catalyst. However, replacing CO2 with CO should not be encouraged because it would reduce the impact of methanol synthesis as a potential method for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. (3) CO + H 2 O ⇌ CO 2 + H 2 Stabilization of the ZnO matrix, in which the copper nanoparticles are usually embedded, seemed desirable [2]. Various promoters have been used in an attempt to maintain the catalyst structure during catalysis with mixed results [9–12]. However, the presented work focuses on a different approach. In previous liquid phase studies, we observed that the sintering behavior of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst depends on the dipole moment ( p → ) of the used solvent [8]. The approach assumes that the solvent adsorbs and replaces surface-bound water, thus reducing the influence of water on the catalyst deactivation (high dipole moment of the solvent corresponds to strong adsorption) [5,8]. This method is now transferred to the gas phase process where additives are added to the feed gas. The choice and concentration of the added compound is crucial, especially with regard to possible poisoning and leaching of the catalyst by the additive and its influence on counteracting deactivation (Fig. 1 ). The purpose of this study is to investigate the impact of deactivation caused by the sintering process on the catalytic properties and activity of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. Additionally, this study aims to evaluate the influence of different additives on the methanol yield and catalyst stability during CO2/H2 conversion. By examining the effects of various additives, particularly their dipole moments, on catalyst performance, this research seeks to identify strategies to enhance catalyst stability while maintaining high catalytic activity. Specifically, the study explores the potential of combining stability-enhancing and activity-enhancing additives to mitigate deactivation and optimize methanol synthesis efficiency. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Argon (Ar, Nippon, 99.999 %), hydrogen (H2, Nippon, 99.999 %), carbon dioxide (CO2, Nippon, 99.995 %), nitrous oxide (N2O, Praxair, 99.995 %), copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2 · 3 H2O, abcr, 99.5 %), zinc(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2 · 6 H2O, abcr, 98 %), aluminum(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3 · 9 H2O, Carl Roth, 98 %), manganese(II) nitrate tetrahydrate (Mn(NO3)2 · 4 H2O, Carl Roth, 99.5 %), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, abcr, 99 %) methanol (CH4O, Carl Roth, 99.9 %), ethanol (C2H6O, Sigma Aldrich, 99.8 %), n-heptane (C7H16, Fluka, 99 %), ethylene glycol (C2H6O2, VEB Laborchemie Apolda, pure, GC–MS analysis has shown no contamination), and 1,2-propylene carbonate (C4H6O3, Sigma Aldrich, 99.7 %) were used without further purification. As shown in Fig. S3, transport limitation by intraparticle diffusion can be neglected. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Variation in the catalytic activities and properties of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts with different degrees of sintering A series of catalysts with different degrees of sintering were used to evaluate the influence of the sintering process on the changes in catalyst properties and catalytic activity. The catalyst was sintered in triethylamine in analogy to our previous work in the liquid phase methanol catalysis [8]. As the experiments were terminated at different reaction times (Table 1 ), five catalysts with different degrees of sintering were obtained. Selective leaching of individual components by the used solvent, triethylamine, during sintering can be neglected because of the catalyst composition is unchanged after a maximum treatment time of 24 h (SI, Fig. S4). Table 1 shows that the average crystal size of Cu and ZnO increases with reaction time indicating a progressively increased degree of sintering (the diffractograms are stated in SI Fig. S5). The ZnO species seems to be particularly affected by crystal growth (LZnO,24h ≈ 6 LZnO,before). However, the Cu to Zn ratio at the surface barely shifts. Since alumina is probably the only component that is not affected by crystal growth, the relative surface Al content increases and the Zn and Cu proportions decrease. The increase in surface oxygen content can be explained by the enrichment of the oxygen-rich alumina on the surface (Si Table S3). As a result, the amount of copper equivalents on the surface decreases as the degree of sintering proceeds. The amount of adsorbable formate also decreases. Thus, it can be concluded that sintering also leads to a decrease in the number of adsorption sites on the catalyst. Formate is widely accepted as a potential key intermediate in the methanol and water gas shift reaction [1,21–25]. This behavior can be seen upon decomposition of the adsorbed formate in the argon stream, where the reactants (CO2/H2) and the products (MeOH/CO) of the respective reactions ( 1 ) and ( 3 ) are observed (SI Fig. S6). The presence of the formate species and its decomposition at approximately 200 °C was also confirmed with in situ DRIFTS (SI Fig. S7). The corresponding activity of the differently sintered catalysts can be compared using the methanol yield at 190 °C (Table 1) or the temperature dependent activity in Fig. 2A. A temperature of 190 °C was chosen because the yield at this temperature was comparatively high (which minimizes errors) and Arrhenius behavior can still be observed (Fig. 2B). The Arrhenius plot was also used to determine the activation energies. These values are very similar for the different sintered catalysts (also to literature [26]: 51.6 ± 0.7 kJ/mol). Fig. 2D shows an approximately linear dependence of catalyst productivity on the amount of surface Cu in catalysts with different degrees of sintering. This behavior indicates that the turnover frequency (TOF) of surface Cu remains largely unchanged during sintering (also demonstrated by Kurtz et al. [4] and stated in Table S4), an interpretation that is further supported by the similar activation energy observed for all catalysts. The consistency of the activation energies and the linear activity relationship with the amount of Cu on the surface suggests that the nature of the active sites remains the same despite sintering. Only the number of these sites decreases as sintering progresses, and so does the yield (Fig. 2C). Copper has also been identified in other studies as the primary component responsible for catalytic activity [27]. In summary, activity loss occurs because of the decrease in the number of active centers on the catalyst during the sintering process, which must be prevented to maintain catalytic activity of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system. 3.2 Impact of additives on the stability and activity of the catalyst in the gas phase As demonstrated by Thrane et al. [28], methanol can enhance methanol yield when used as an additive because of its autocatalytic behavior. To further explore changes in activity induced by different additives during the gas-phase process, both activity-enhancing and potentially stability-improving components were examined. The first group, primarily methanol and ethanol, was selected for their potential to alter the reaction mechanism. This mechanism-altering effect refers to enhancements in catalytic activity that are not merely the result of poisoning mitigation. These additives have been extensively studied in both liquid- and gas-phase catalytic systems [28–32]. For ethanol, a reaction mechanism has been proposed based on the formation of formic acid from CO2 and H2, subsequent esterification with ethanol to ethyl formate, and subsequent hydrogenation to methanol and ethanol [29]. Unlike ethanol, the autocatalytic reaction mechanism involving methanol has also been confirm for the catalytic hydrogenation of syngas in the gas-phase [1,28]. The activity-enhancing effect of added methanol in CO2/H2 methanol synthesis is further supported by the experimental results presented in Fig. 3 . A decrease in activity at higher temperatures is due to a thermodynamic limitation of reaction ( 1 ) when methanol is added to the feed. In contrast, no change in activity is observed for the addition EtOH compared to the conventional process. Therefore, it needs to be stated that the addition of ethanol that looked promising in the liquid phase does not lead to an improvement in the gas phase [8,29]. Ethanol can be labeled as unsuitable as an additive, unlike methanol, which can be used as an activity-enhancing component. Regarding the second group of additives, including n-heptane, propylene carbonate (PC), and ethylene glycol (Etgly), selected for their varying dipole moments and potential stability-enhancing effects, their influence on potential catalyst poisoning is of particular interest. For the addition of n-heptane no difference to the process without additives can be observed. The adsorption strength is presumably very weak with a dipole moment of 0 C m and therefore does not lead to poisoning of the catalyst. For Etgly ( p → Etgly = 7.3·10−30 C m) [33], the strongest decrease in activity (compared to the other additives) can be observed below temperatures of 230 °C. However, the fact that this behavior is reversible can be recognized by the increase in yield between 235 and 250 °C. This indicates strong poisoning by ethylene glycol. A possible catalytic effect of Etgly, as shown for MeOH, is unlikely due to the structural similarity to EtOH, which also caused no increase in catalytic activity. Because of the drastic loss in activity, ethylene glycol has not been considered further. Propylene carbonate (investigated only from 200 to 260 °C due to its high boiling point) has with 17.9·10−30 C m the highest dipole moment of the investigated liquids [34]. Fig. 3 shows a decrease in activity when PC is used. This effect can probably also be explained by a possible poisoning of the catalyst. However, although the dipole moment of PC is larger than the one of Etgly, the observed activity decrease is lower. Thus, it can be assumed that other properties may also be relevant. Furthermore, selective leaching of catalyst components was not observed for any of the additives studied (SI Fig. S9). In addition to the changes in catalytic activity caused by the different additives, the stability of the catalyst with respect to the presence H2O was studied by adding solvent/water mixtures to the reactant stream. The sintering process that takes place in the liquid phase can be attributed to the influence of water ( p → water = 6.1·10−30 C m) [35]. In order to address the sintering in the gas phase water has been added to the reactant stream to investigate this phenomenon in an accelerated manner. This influence can be seen in Fig. 4 . The remaining activity after 24 h of treatment of the catalyst with steam at the reaction temperature is <50 %. When other additives such as EtOH, MeOH, or PC are added along with water, the loss of activity can be reduced. PC performed best in this stability study with an activity loss of 17 %. Therefore, the subsequent activity could be increased by the presence of an additive with a high dipole moment and the influence of the added water on the sintering process was reduced, however, it could not be suppressed completely. The remaining activity of water/MeOH ( p → MeOH = 5.6·10−30 C m) [36] also improved compared to the one in the experiment with only water added, which may indicate competitive adsorption between methanol and water on the catalyst (due to the dipole moment similar to that of water) and an entropic effect, resulting from the dilution of the added water. n-heptane could not be included in these studies because it is not miscible with water. In the subsequent characterization of the spent catalysts, it is evident from the surface composition that the catalyst before, after the gas phase catalysis (without additive), and the catalyst treated with a water/PC mixture have similar ratios with respect to the Cu, Zn and Al contents. Especially when considering the treatment with water/MeOH and water, it is noticeable that severe deviations in the surface composition occur, corresponding to the greater activity losses. As in 3.1 for the sintered catalysts, there is also an accumulation of Al and oxygen (SI, Table S5) and a depletion of Cu and Zn, the actual active components. The reason for this behavior can presumably be deducted from the XRD pattern in Fig. 4. During the treatment without addition of additives and water/PC, there was hardly any crystal growth of Cu and ZnO, while water/MeOH, water/EtOH and water clearly show narrower and more intense reflections, suggesting larger crystals compared to the catalyst before, especially for ZnO. The crystal sizes according to the Scherrer equation are also given in SI Table S6 for comparison. The XRD pattern of the catalyst after the water/EtOH treatment is noteworthy. Already in the liquid phase studies, catalysts which performed the catalysis in alcohols showed an increased degree of sintering [6,8]. These phenomena were explained by the large amounts of methanol (and thus water) formed. However, it appears that alcohols also accelerate the sintering rate, at least of ZnO, regardless of the increased quantity of water. Therefore, with the exception of methanol, alkanols are not suitable for application in methanol catalysis, especially for the stabilization of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system. Furthermore, the XRD pattern of the catalyst after the treatment with water/EtOH shows that two different sizes of zinc oxide crystals seem to be present side by side, particularly visible in the ZnO reflections between 30 and 40°. Both large crystals (recognizable by the intense, narrow reflections) and small crystals similar to the previous catalyst (less intense and broad) can be distinguished. In the liquid phase studies, this behavior was interpreted as the growth of the zinc oxide according to the Ostwald riping mechanism [8]. Accordingly, Zn(OH)2 is formed from ZnO and water, which melts, accumulates statistically and decomposes to become zinc oxide again. The case shown here appears to be similar to the liquid phase experiments and suggests that the deactivation mechanism in the gas phase could be comparable to that in the liquid phase. This effect would also explain the fact that propylene carbonate performs very well in this stability study, as the PC (like in the liquid phase process) could be adsorbed on the catalyst instead of water. The competitive adsorption of propylene carbonate is also supported by the observed decrease in catalytic activity in the presence of small amounts of PC (Fig. 3, corresponding to poisoning). To combine both positive effects, a mixture of methanol (activity-enhancing component) and propylene carbonate (stability-enhancing component) is used for the following long-term measurement. In SI Fig. S10 different compositions of PC/MeOH were tested for their catalytic activity. At low PC contents (5–6 at%) the positive influence of methanol dominates, at higher concentrations (10–15 at%) the poisoning by PC is more pronounced. Therefore, a methanol solution containing propylene carbonate with 6 at% PC was used for the long-term measurement in 3.3. The addition of this mixture maintains catalytic activity comparable to that of the conventional methanol synthesis process, while the presence of the highly polar compound propylene carbonate potentially enhances the long-term stability of the system. 3.3 Catalytic long-term measurements with and without additives To assess the stability-enhancing effects of the propylene carbonate and methanol mixture during catalysis, a long-term experiment was performed, followed by detailed characterization of the recovered catalyst. Fig. 5 presents a comparison of the long-term performance with and without the addition of the PC/MeOH mixture. A low feed volume flow (and thus high yields) was chosen to accelerate the deactivation. Due to the generally lower methanol yield with PC/MeOH, this process was carried out for 14.5d, while the process without additives was limited to 14d. As a result, the amounts of water formed during methanol and CO synthesis are similar (vwater,gaseous(PC/MeOH) = 47L, vwater,gaseous(without additives) = 51L). The addition of MeOH led to a catalysis close to the thermodynamic equilibrium of the reaction ( 1 ) and thus a possible deactivation of the catalyst would have little to no effect on the observed methanol yield. Therefore, a reliable statement about the activity loss during the long-term measurement is only possible for the case without additives. For this reason, after the long-term measurement, the spent catalysts were reused to evaluate the differences in the remaining activity in separate experiments. The activity loss of approximately 27 % for the conventional gas phase process is also evident in the long-term measurement. The remaining activity of the catalyst that performed the long-term catalysis with PC/MeOH added to the reactant stream is substantially higher than that of the catalysis without additives. The spent catalysts were also characterized by XRD, XPS and BET. Fig. 5 shows the difference to the catalyst before catalysis, in the SI the Tables S7–S9 state the absolute values. The XRD patterns in Fig. 5 indicate the positive influence of the additives on the zinc oxide crystal size. Compared to the standard gas phase process, this catalyst exhibits broad and less intense ZnO reflections, particularly noticeable in the 30°–40° range. The difference between both cases, quantified by the Scherrer equation, also suggests an approximately threefold increase in the mean zinc oxide crystal size in the additive-free long-term experiment compared to the increase in the mean zinc oxide crystal size of the catalyst treated with PC/MeOH. No advantage of the mitigation of the Cu-sintering was observed by the addition of PC/MeOH. As a result of the different stages of sintering of the catalysts, the specific surface area of the catalysts also decreases to varying degrees (Table S8). The decrease in surface area for the long-term experiment without additives is about three times greater than that with the additives. These changes are quantitatively similar as the differences in activity loss between the two spent catalysts. The surface composition of the catalyst treated with PC/MeOH is similar to that of the catalyst before catalysis. Again, an enrichment of Al and a depletion of Cu and Zn can be observed, but this effect is much greater for the catalyst after the conventional gas phase process. The different catalysts were also investigated by TEM (Fig. 6 ). The Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system before catalysis (Fig. 6A) shows the typical structure for these catalysts. Copper nanoparticles are embedded in a ZnO matrix. After the long-term experiment without additives, this structure is changed considerably (Fig. 6C). There are single, very large ZnO crystals and the previously existing zinc oxide matrix has been disrupted by the crystal growth. As a consequence of the destroyed zinc oxide matrix, two copper nanoparticles collided and formed a larger Cu crystal (Fig. 6C). Bigger ZnO crystals can also be seen after the treatment with additives (Fig. 6B), but not as large as in the catalyst after the conventional gas phase process. The TEM measurements therefore indicate similar results compared to the Scherrer equation. In general, the remaining structure with the PC/MeOH approach is comparable to the previous catalyst, which also suggests a positive effect of the additives. For example, in Fig. 6B, a copper nanoparticle can be seen that is still embedded in the matrix, similar to the catalyst before the catalysis. The general changes in properties shown in Fig. 6 correspond well with the changes described in 3.1 and 3.2. It can therefore be assumed that the sintering behavior during gas phase catalysis is accelerated by the addition of water or by carrying out the catalysis in the liquid phase, but that the sintering mechanism itself is not changed. Thus, in the future, the deactivation behavior of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst can be studied in a more timely and efficient manner using these two methods. 4 Conclusion The effect of varying sintering degrees on the catalytic activity of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system in gas-phase CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was investigated. The observed loss in activity due to deactivation is not attributed to changes in the nature of the active sites but rather to a reduction in their number, resulting from the crystal growth of Cu and ZnO. This growth is likely induced by adsorbed water on the catalyst surface, highlighting the need to suppress such water-induced sintering. To address this issue, additives with varying dipole moments were introduced into the feed during the gas-phase process to displace water from the catalyst surface. Among these, propylene carbonate (PC), a highly polar compound and a CO2-derived chemical, was particularly effective in improving the water tolerance of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. However, PC also caused catalyst poisoning due to its strong adsorption. This loss in activity was counterbalanced by co-feeding methanol, which enhances the reaction rate via an autocatalytic mechanism, as previously demonstrated by Thrane et al. [28]. The combined addition of PC and MeOH (6 at%/94 at%) proved effective in long-term studies, reducing deactivation to approximately one-third of that observed in conventional methanol synthesis. Furthermore, catalyst characteristics such as surface composition, crystal size, and specific surface area were better maintained under these conditions. This novel approach enables methanol synthesis using CO2 as the sole carbon source by partially mitigating catalyst deactivation caused by water formation, without the need for CO co-feeding. coredata.dc:description: The impact of catalyst deactivation due to sintering on the activity and properties of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was systematically investigated. Additionally, the effects of various additives on methanol yield and catalyst stability during CO2/H2 hydrogenation were evaluated. Additives such as methanol were confirmed to enhance catalytic activity, while components with high dipole moments exhibited a poisoning effect. Interestingly, despite their deactivating influence on activity, these polar additives significantly improved catalyst stability. It is presumed that highly polar species adsorb onto the catalyst surface, displacing water that would otherwise promote crystal growth of copper and zinc oxides, leading to deactivation. A combined additive strategy using methanol (to boost activity) and propylene carbonate (to enhance stability) offers a novel approach to significantly slow down Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst deactivation during gas-phase CO2 hydrogenation, without compromising initial activity compared to conventional additive-free systems. Thus, catalyst stability can be effectively improved through the addition of appropriate components to the feed, without sacrificing reaction rate.
